name: Cape Wrath Trail (Fort William → Invergarry → Morvich)

ai.summary: Cape Wrath Trail is a renowned long-distance trek in Scotland, covering roughly 248.6 km from Fort William to Morvich via Invergarry. It traverses rugged Highland landscape, including lochs, moorland, forests, and remote coastal sections, demanding stamina, navigation, and resilience to variable weather.
ai.terrain_summary: Terrain ranges from boggy moorland and peat flats to rocky ridges, forest tracks, and river crossings. Expect steep ascents and descents, long days on exposed terrain, and remote sections with limited resupply. Coastal and tidal segments near Cape Wrath add additional navigation and timing considerations.
ai.safety_notes: Plan for rapidly changing weather and limited rescue access. Carry detailed map and compass (GPS backup), know your route and tide times for coastal sections, and inform someone of your itinerary. The route is remote with limited cell service; carry a personal locator beacon or satellite messenger, sufficient food and water, proper insulation, and a well-fitted pack. Start early, monitor weather, and carry a contingency plan for bad conditions or injury.
recommended_gear: Sturdy waterproof hiking boots with ankle support
Waterproof and breathable outer layers (jacket and trousers)
Insulating layers (fleece or down, hat and gloves)
Map and compass (GPS as backup) and knowledge of navigation
First aid kit and personal medications
Emergency beacon or satellite messenger (PLB/IR device)
Lightweight tent or bivy sack + sleeping system
Sleeping bag suitable for cool to cold temperatures
Stove, fuel, and lightweight cookset (or cold meals if preferred)
Enough high-energy food and snacks for multi-day segments
Water purification method (filter, tablets) or water bottles with purification capability
Whistle, multi-tool or knife, duct tape
Spare clothing and socks, repair kit
ai.best_seasons: Late spring to early autumn (roughly May–September) is preferable for the Cape Wrath Trail, with the best conditions typically in June–August. Winter travel is possible only with advanced mountaineering experience and extra precautions.
